questions.question:
Question 1: For a patient presenting with gradual, painless diminution of vision, the differential diagnosis 
would not include  
.
questions.explanation: Methyl alcohol amblyopia causes sudden painless diminution of vision. It is a toxic neuropathy of the optic nerve.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?
questions.explanation:
563 
Sold by @itachibot The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellens chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes. Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to 
discriminate between two points. Snellens chart is used for Visual acuity assesment. In snellens chart the alphabets decrease in size as we move from above-downwards and these 
lines, from above-downwards should be read at 60, 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6, 5 and 4 m respectively. At 
these distances, the respective letters subtend a visual angle of 5 minutes. Hence, the largest 
alphabet that should be read at 60 m subtends a visual angle of 5 minutes in the eye.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 60-year-old man comes to the OPD for an eye exam. He is having difficulty reading 
newspapers but has no problem watching television. At what distance would you ask him to 
read a Jaeger's chart from?
questions.explanation:
Jaeger’s chart is held at a distance of 35 cm away from the patient. 564 
Sold by @itachibot It is used to measure near vision. The smallest letter is designated as N5 or J1 and the largest as 
N48. Snellen's near vision chart can also be used. The image below shows a Jaeger's chart.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient is being evaluated for a recent eye injury. The result of his Placido disc test is shown 
below. What is the correct interpretation? 551 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given Placido’s disc test result indicates a normal corneal surface. This test is used to detect an abnormal corneal surface. Irregularities of the corneal surface 
cause distortion of the circles. Distortion of the circle is seen in keratoconus, keratoglobus, corneal ulcer, and corneal abrasion. 565 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient presents with the following finding in his eye. Fluorescein staining is done and the 
eye is observed under cobalt blue light. What would be seen?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a corneal ulcer. The ulcer takes the stain and appears brilliant green, and when 
examined under cobalt blue light, it appears opaque green.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 61-year-old man, known case of diabetes mellitus, presented with headache and eye pain. 
He also reports difficulty with driving at night. Visual field-testing indicates peripheral vision 
loss. The ophthalmologist uses the following instrument during his examination of this 
patient. What is he measuring by using the following instrument?
questions.explanation:
The instrument shown is the Schiotz tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure 
(IOP). This patient's complaints of headache, eye pain, difficulty in adapting to darkness, and 
examination findings of peripheral vision loss with increased intraocular pressure, is suggestive of 
glaucoma. Schiotz tonometer is a type of indentation tonometer. The principle behind its use is that 
the plunger will indent a soft eye more than a hard eye.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image? 553 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The concept of the procedure was introduced by Goldmann.
options.b: It is used to treat after cataract
options.c: It is based on the Imbert-Fick law
options.d: It is used to investigate glaucoma

questions.explanation:
The instrument shown is an applanation tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular 
pressure (IOP). The concept behind the procedure was introduced by Goldmann. It is based on Imbert-Fick law, 
which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its 
surface divided by the area of flattening (A). P = W/A The different types are Goldmann tonometer, Perkin’s tonometer, pneumatic tonometer, pulse air 
tonometer, tono-pen. 566 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for his myopia. He is now complaining of 
headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on him.
questions.explanation:
The above image is of the dynamic contour tonometer such as the Pascal tonometer. The dynamic 
contour tonometer(Pascal) offers a non-invasive and direct method of intraocular pressure (IOP) 
measurement with an additional measurement of the ocular pulse amplitude. This type of 
tonometer is unaffected by the corneal thickness and it is the tonometer of choice in post-Lasik 
patients. Option A: Pachymetry is used to measure the corneal thickness. The below image is of pachymetry. Option C: Auto Refractotemetry is a computerized refractometer that is used to find out the error 
of refraction. This gives rapid information about the kind of refractive error in terms of sphere, 
cylinder with axis and inter pupillary distance. Option D: A-Scan ultrasonography is a useful diagnostic tool for intraocular evaluation especially 
in the setting of opaque media. The report of the A scan is displayed as a unidimensional display 
of spikes along a baseline where the distance between the spikes gives the indirect measurement 
of the tissues. A-scan is used to measure • The axial length of the eyeball for Intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation • Anterior chamber depth • Thickness of intraocular mass. A-scan ultrasonography is shown in the image below. 567 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: You can use any of the following to estimate the visual field of a patient except:
questions.explanation:
Optical coherence tomography is not used to estimate the visual field. It is a non-invasive imaging 
technique to visualize cross-sections of the retina. Perimetry is used to estimate the visual field. Types: • Manual perimetry- Confrontation method, Lister’s perimeter, Campimetry (Scotometry), 
Goldmann’s perimeter • Automated perimetry- Octopus Fieldmaster, Humphrey Field Analyzer The images given below shows Lister's perimeter 568 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows a multifixation campimeter study result.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which among the following phases indicate complete filling of the retinal arterioles and 
capillaries on fundus fluorescein angiography?
questions.explanation:
Complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries is seen in the arterio-venous phase. In FFA, sodium fluorescein dye is injected into the antecubital vein. A fundus camera is then used 
to take photographs: • 1st picture- after 5 seconds, then every second for 20 seconds, every 3–5 seconds for the next 1 
minute • Last picture- after 10 minutes • Pre-arterial phase- choroidal circulation is filling 569 
Sold by @itachibot • Arterial phase- start filling of retinal arteriole till its completely filled • Arterio-venous phase- complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries followed by laminar 
filling of veins • Venous filling- arterioles are emptying and veins are filling Indications for fundus fluorescein angiography: • Diabetic retinopathy • Vascular occlusion • Eale’s disease • Central serous retinopathy • Cystoid macular edema

questions.question:
Question 11: A 55-year-old patient with diabetes presents with complaints of dark floating spots and 
flashes of light in her left eye. Optical coherence tomography of the left eye is given in the 
image below. Identify the pathology. 555 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows vitreomacular traction with detached posterior vitreous membrane and foveal 
traction. OCT images: 1. Normal OCT 570 
Sold by @itachibot 2. Vitreomacular traction- The fovea is elevated from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), as 
indicated by the arrow. Pseudocysts and retinal morphology distortion may also be seen at the site 
of traction. 3. Vitreomacular adhesion- posterior vitreous detachment but no macular or foveal traction. The 
retinal morphology is normal. 571 
Sold by @itachibot 4. Macular hole - a partial or full-thickness retinal defect is seen. A full-thickness macular hole is seen in the image below. 5. Central serous retinopathy- fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal 
detachment. 572 
Sold by @itachibot 6. Cystoid macular edema - loss of foveal depression with cystoid spaces in the retina.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 50-year-old female, who is a known case of type 2 diabetes, is undergoing serial 
electroretinograms to monitor disease progression. The following finding was obtained from 
her recent test. What does the wave marked by the arrow indicate?
questions.explanation:
The wave marked is the "B" wave. It represents the activity of bipolar cells. Electroretinogram (ERG) is used to detect the functional abnormality of the outer retina up to the 
bipolar cells. 573 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: You would classify the electrooculography (EOG) of a patient as subnormal if the Arden ratio 
is less than  
.
questions.explanation:
In electrooculography (EOG), the subnormal curve is <150. EOG is based on the measurement of the resting membrane potential of the eye between 
the cornea (+) and the back of the eye (-). Interpretation is based on the Arden ratio. Arden Ratio = Max height of light peak/Min height of dark trough × 100 • Normal curve: 185 or above • Subnormal curve: <150 • Flat curve: <125 574 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: You can use 'A' scan for all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Assessment of vitreous hemorrhage is done by "B" scan. Both 'A' and 'B' scans are types of ultrasound (USG) scans. The first image below shows "A" scan ultrasound amplitude spikes. The second image shows a normal "B" scan of the eye. A scan (time amplitude) 
B scan (intensity modulation) Itproduces atwo-dimensional It produces a unidimensional 
image and echoes are plotte 
d as spikes. dotted section of the eyeball. Uses:Assessment of the poste 
rior segment in opaque medi 
aStudy of intraocular tumors 
Localization of intraocular an 
d intra-orbital foreign bodies Uses:Axial lengthIntraocular 
lens (IOL) power calculation: 
BiometryAnterior chamber d 
epthThe thickness of intraoc 
ular mass 575 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is false regarding the instrument in the image? 557 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is used to test macular function
options.b: It is used to measure vertical, horizontal tropias, and phorias
options.c: It cannot be used to measure cyclodeviation
options.d: It is based on diplopic projection

questions.explanation:
The image shows a Maddox rod. Cyclodeviation is measured with the double Maddox rod test. The Maddox rod test uses a specially constructed device consisting of a series of parallel cylinders 
that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with 
another Maddox rod, for cyclodeviations.

questions.question:
Question 16: A woman came to the OPD due to blurring of vision while working on her laptop. 
Retinoscopy was performed at 1 m without cycloplegia. The red reflex moves in the same 
direction as the retinoscope. Which of the following refractive errors is not possible in this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
A patient with 1 D myopia would exhibit no movement of red reflex when retinoscopy is done 
from a distance of 1m without cycloplegia. 576 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: You can use keratometry for all of the following except:

options.c: Calculating the power of the intraocular lens (IOL)
options.d: Calculating the power of lens in spectacles

questions.explanation:
Keratometry or ophthalmometry is not used to calculate the power of the lens in spectacles. Uses of keratometry: • Estimate corneal astigmatism • Measure the curvature of the cornea • Calculate the power of the intraocular lens (IOL) The image given below shows keratometry being performed on a patient. 577 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: An old man comes to the OPD for an annual eye exam. The ophthalmologist examines his 
fundus as shown below. Identify the procedure.
questions.explanation: The procedure shown is direct ophthalmoscopy. It is used to visualize the fundus. Types: • Direct ophthalmoscopy • Distant direct ophthalmoscopy • Indirect ophthalmoscopy

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following statements is false about direct ophthalmoscopy?

options.c: The type of image formed is real and inverted.
options.d: A condensing lens is not needed.

questions.explanation: The type of image formed in direct ophthalmoscopy is virtual and erect.

questions.question:
Question 20: Which among the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image? 559 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The principle is to make eye emmetropic.
options.b: Image is real, inverted, and magnified.
options.d: It may be done even in patient's with a hazy media.

questions.explanation:
The procedure is indirect ophthalmoscopy and its principle is to make the eye highly myopic. A convex lens is used, commonly +20D. The image formed is real, inverted, and magnified. It is 
used for assessing and managing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions. It may 
be done with hazy media because of strong inbuilt illumination.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following can you assess using Holmgren's wool-matching test?
questions.explanation:
Holmgren's wool-matching test is used for the assessment of color vision. Tests for color vision • Ishihara pseudo-isochromatic chart • There are 38 plates read at a distance of 75 cm. • Drawback- Cannot detect a blue color defect • Hardy–Rand–Rittler test • City University test • Holmgren's wool-matching test • Naegels anamoloscope • Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue test The image given below shows Ishihara pseudo-isochromatic chart 578 
Sold by @itachibot FüfFS¥/0ńh-MUfiS9II100-hue test City University
 test 579 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: What is the name of the dye in the strip? 560 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given dye in the strip is lissamine green. It is used as 1% concentration. Lissamine green stains dead and degenerate cells, but does not stain healthy epithelial cells. It is 
used to diagnose ocular surface disease. It stains the conjunctiva. It does not cause stinging like Rose Bengal. The Green staining is best 
observed two minutes after instillation. The image below shows the lissamine staining of the eye. 580 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: The device shown below cannot be used in the management of which of the following?
questions.explanation: The image shows a cryoprobe. It is not used in the management of impending corneal perforation. It is used in: • Peripheral retinopexy for peripherally located retinal breaks and tears • Treatment of anterior RB tumors • Cyclocryotherapy in pars planitis and end-stage glaucoma

questions.question: Question 24: The following image indicates:
questions.explanation:
The given image is suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy. The central image shows the primary position of gaze where the patient's left eye is deviated down 
and out with ptosis of the left eyelid. From the eye movements in other positions, it can be seen 
that adduction and elevation are absent and depression is reduced in the left eye. All of these 
findings are indicative of oculomotor nerve palsy. 3rd Cranial nerve(oculomotor nerve) palsy presents with: • Ptosis due to weakness of levator palpebrae superioris muscle (LPS) • Abduction and depression in the primary position (down and out) due to unopposed action of 
the lateral rectus(6th nerve supply) and superior oblique muscles(4th nerve supply) • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy (involvement of 
Edinger Westphal parasympathetic supply) • Limited adduction, elevation and depression due to ipsilateral paralysis of medial rectus, inferior 
oblique and inferior rectus . Option A: Trochlear(4th cranial) nerve palsy presents with superior oblique muscle paralysis. Clinical findings of trochlear nerve palsy include: 581 
Sold by @itachibot • Hypertropia (elevation) in the primary position • Extorsion that is greatest in abduction • Compensatory head posture with contralateral face turn and head tilt with chin slightly 
depressed. This position is assumed to avoid Diplopia. • Limitation of depression • Normal abduction and elevation. The below given image depicts 4th cranial nerve palsy. Option B: Lateral rectus palsy is seen in cases of isolated Abducens nerve palsy. These patients 
present with esotropia/convergent squint in primary position with limitation of abduction on the 
side of the lesion. This is due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle in the affected eye. There is also a compensatory head turn towards the side of the lesion to reduce the symptom of 
Diplopia. The adduction is normal in lateral rectus palsy. 582 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Internuclear opthalmoplegia occurs following an injury to the medial longitudinal 
fasciculus (MLF). A unilateral lesion to the MLF leads to the failure of adduction in the ipsilateral 
eye with a normal abduction of the contralateral eye. The below given image depicts the pathogenesis of Inter nuclear opthalmoplegia in detail.

questions.question: Question 25: Photostress test is used to differentiate between:
questions.explanation:
Photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve. This test is of particular use in early macular diseases such as central serous retinopathy. In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. 
A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line 
again, and the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye. 583 
Sold by @itachibot In normal people and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. 
Whereas, in patients with macular disease the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than 
one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are 
damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process. 584 
Sold by @itachibot Eye Signs in Systemic Disease
